Authors: Chen, CY; Gan, S; Yuan, XP; Lv, J
Author Full Names: Chen, Chunyan; Gan, Shu; Yuan, Xiping; Lv, Jie
Article Title: Suitability Evaluation and Analysis for Mountainious Tea Garden Land Supported by GIS Application
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: mountanious land; teaplanting land use; suitability evaluation; GIS; spatial analysis
Abstract: Teaplanting land use or tea garden is one of the dominating land use type in Yunnan mountainious region. It is significant about suitability evaluation and analysis for tea garden land scientifically integrated with mountainious land resources feature, since it is benefit to distribute mountainious land resources use by adjust measures to local conditions and promote local mountainious land resources sustainable use for long time. The study chose tea garden land suitability evaluation of Ning'er county in Yunnan Province as the research target. Based on the analyzing of the relationship between tea plant growing and natural condition and the condition of tea garden maintenance, the paper chose land suitability evaluation indexes of tea garden. The annual temperature, annual rainfall factor were simulated using ARCGIS interpolated method. The evaluation quantitative classification table was build with the annual temperature, annual rainfall, soilt, slope, irrigation water sources and road accessibility. Finally, integrated use ARCGIS spatial analysis, spatial jion assigned the scores of each role to evaluation unit polygons, and calculating the general score of the factors, to achieve the tea garden land suitability evaluation. Analysed the spatial layout of the evaluation results: the study area can be divided into the most suitable areas, sub-suitable areas, critical suitable areas and unsuitable areas, and further analysis and discussion of the evaluation results was done.

Article Title: On the Necessity of Coexistence of Different Contractual Concepts in the Period of Social Transition
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: the concept of contract; contractual relationship; intersubjectivity; favor society
Abstract: The communication link among the contact subjects have the characteristics of both blood ties and equal status, because of the different ways of meeting material interests and this situation determines the co-existence of non-intersubjectivity and intersubjectivity in the relationship among contact subjects in the period of social transition.. The concept of contract is a reflection of the intrinsic value of contractual relationship. Different concepts of contract result from different contractual relationship, and different contractual relationship is the reflection of different favor relationship. The different nature of the relationship among the contact subjects leds to the different concepts of contract in the period of social transition.

Article Title: Approaches regarding the specific provisions for credit risk in the context of IFRS application by the romanian baking system
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: national regulations; IFRSs; provisions specific to credit risk; fair value; amortized cost; guarantees
Abstract: The actual global financial crisis bore out the important role which the financial stability has within both the financial system and the economy as a whole. The IFRS implementation within the Romanian banking system generated real challenges regarding the accommodation of the banks' internal rules to the new requirements. Even though the normative documentation which concerns the IFRSs adoption by Romanian banks starting from 1st of January 2012 was issued, the prudential and fiscal regulations concerning its application are still pending. The main objective of this paper is to emphasize the impact which IFRSs have on the Romanian banking system as far as the quantification and accounting treatment of the provisions specific to risk are concerned. In regards to this article, the methods applied here consist in a deductive-type research, in which the starting point is represented by general facts in order to get to particular ones, starting from a theory that has as purpose the application of that certain prediction, by assuring a wider area of knowledge and being more operational. The selection of the pieces of information was done through different methods, as the quantitative and the qualitative research types. The pieces of information presented here were picked up from different sources, i.e. published articles and specialized books, all being taken from the financial field. The general conclusions regarding the topic of the provisions specific to credit risk in the actual context of the global financial crisis are presented at the end of the paper.

Article Title: REGENERATING MARKET ATTACHMENTS Consumer credit debt collection and the capture of affect
Author Keywords: market attachment; captation; affect; market devices; dispositions
Abstract: Drawing together insights from key figures in the collections industry and observation at one of the UK's largest debt purchasers, this paper opens up the socio-material mechanisms of 'market attachment' through which, drawing on Franck Cochoy, the potential 'captation' of the defaulting consumer credit debtor occurs. It begins by setting out the analytical deficits in the contemporary analysis of consumer debt collection practices, before tracing the industry's responses to the particular problematic of consumer collections. It focuses on the role played by the 'capture of affect' in collections processes, building on existing work exploring socio-economic objects that may be described as 'non-representational'. A richer understanding of the relationship between markets and the body is thus brought to Actor-Network Theory influenced studies of processes of 'economization'. It follows the debtor's progress along collections 'trajectories', exploring different not necessarily compatible modes of captation being deployed by collectors attempting to enact defaulters as repayers, ranging from the quasi-therapeutic to the disciplinary. It concludes by examining the increasing role for performative forms of in vitro and in vivo experimentation being deployed in the collections process, through the use of econometric modelling techniques. Both the debtors' pasts and their actions as they move through the present are shown to provide the empirical grounding for a process of repeated affective 'testing', aimed at discovering - and profiting from - minute variations in debtor dispositions.

Article Title: CONCENTRATION OF BOTANICALLY INTERESTING PIECES OF KNOWLEDGE IN LOCALITIES OF VYSOKOMVTSKO-MICROREGION
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: Pardubice Region; phytocenological frame; spectrum of life forms; vegetation; Vysoke Myto; Vysokomytsko microregion
Abstract: The aim of the paper was to concentrate pieces of knowledge of botanically interesting sites in Vysokomytsko microregion. This paper directly builds on the existing scientific and mainly botanical studies in Vysokomytsko microregion. Botanically significant locations were separately processed, information about existing biologically significant sites, protected areas and memorial trees were taken from the literature. The theoretical part of the work focuses on Vysokomytsko microregion and its topographical definition and natural conditions. The practical part deals with some interesting botanical sites in Vysokomytsko microregion. There were 15 botanically interesting sites, 4 existing biologically significant sites, two protected areas and memorial trees. The studied sites are located in Vysoke Myto and its surroundings. The next part is focused on existing biologically important locations Knirov - Vanice, Vinice, Vraclav and municipal park. The last part deals with the existing protected areas natural landmark U Vinic, natural landmark Vstavacova louka and memorial trees. The Vysokomytsko microregion survey was conducted using standard floristic and phytocenological methods. Phytocenological frames and spectra of life forms were created for botanically interesting sites. The flora's list of studied sites was listed in the summary floristic table to clarity and comparison.

Abstract: Purpose - theoretical and empirical investigation of interrelation between standard of living as a competitiveness effect and competitiveness itself (productivity) of 14 regions and 2 cities in Kazakhstan. Methodology - Simple regression model is used to approach the problem. Originality/value - Approach is original in a way of looking at causal effect direction between two parameters of the model. Findings - Results suggest that there is a positive and significant but not strong relationship between standard of living and competitiveness in regions of Kazakhstan.

Article Title: An Empirical Study the Relationship between Low-Carbon Consumption and Consumer Perceived Value-Hotel Services as an Example
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: low-carbon consumption; consumer perceived value; structural equation modeling; hotels
Abstract: Low-carbon consumption has been concerned recently and hotel is an important field for promoting low-carbon consumption, so what the relationship is between Low-carbon consumption and consumer perceived value is worthy of studying. A total of 202 samples were analyzed with exploratory factor analysis (EFA) and structural equation modeling (SEM). Findings indicate that consumer perceived value comprise of functional value (performance/quality), functional value (price/value for money), social value, emotional value, epistemic value dimensions, and low-carbon consumption has a significant impact on these value dimensions. Theoretical and realistic implications and suggestions for future research are discussed in the end.

Article Title: What Should We Be Teaching in Basic Economics Courses?
Author Keywords: AP economics; basic economics; public choice
Abstract: Advanced Placement economics leaves thousands of high school students with a misleading impression of modern economics. The courses fail to cover key sources of growth and prosperity, including private ownership, dynamic competition, and entrepreneurship. The tools of public choice economics are totally ignored. Government is modeled as a corrective device available to impose ideal solutions. Market failure is covered, but there is no such thing as government failure. The macroeconomics course reflects the simplistic 1960s Keynesian view of stabilization policy. Time lags, incentive effects, secondary effects of budget deficits, and other factors that complicate effective use of stabilization policy are almost entirely ignored. In contrast, the 20 Voluntary National Content Standards in Economics of the Council for Economic Education illustrate what a balanced course in modern economics would look like.

Article Title: The Discussion of China Resource-Based Enterprises Risk Management of Overseas M&A
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6

Abstract: Under the background of economic globalization, China Resource-based enterprises carry out capital expansion through Cross-Border Mergers and Acquisitions, enhancing the bargaining power on resource prices, and reduce their dependence on imports of resources. Firstly, in this paper the characteristic and motives of China resources-based enterprises are analyzed. Article Title: An Empirical Study Design on the Acceptance of the Government Performance Auditing in China
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: government performance auditing; behavior will (or acceptance); the theory of planned behavior
Abstract: As the growing public expense and the increasing democratic consciousness, there is a tendency to develop performance auditing in the world and the acceptance of the government performance auditing (GPA) is quite important for the GPA development. This work analysis the various factors related to the acceptance of GPA based on the theory of planned behavior from the perspective of auditees. We posit that the acceptance of GPA would be influenced significantly by the attitude to the GPA, the perceived organization support to GPA, difficulties in metric selecting and performance evaluation and the perceived importance of auditing results.

Article Title: Study on the Mutual Effects and Conduction Mechanism between Rural Surplus Labor's Transfer and Urban-Rural Integration-An Empirical Analysis of Chongqing
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: Rural Surplus Labors' Transfer; Urban-Rural Integration; Conduction Mechanism
Abstract: Urban-rural integration is not only the result but also the precondition of rural surplus labor's transfer. This paper is to empirically analyze the mutual effects between rural surplus labor's transfer and urban-rural integration with the Simultaneous-Equations Econometric Model, to find out the conduction mechanism between them. And it is found that, the effects rural surplus labor's transfer has on urban-rural integration is negative at first, which turns positive with an elastic coefficient of 0.148 as time goes by, accelerating the development of urban-rural integration. Having a function of balancing rural surplus labor's transfer, urban-rural integration has positive effects on rural surplus labor's transfer, whose influence degree is greater than what rural surplus labor's transfer has.

Article Title: ECONOMIC ROLE OF CLUSTER IN INCREASING THE COMPETITIVENESS OF KAZAKHSTAN ECONOMY
Source Title: VITH RYSKULOV READINGS: SOCIO-ECONOMIC MODERNIZATION OF KAZAKHSTAN UNDER CONDITIONS OF GLOBAL FINANCIAL INSTABILITY
Conference Title: International Scientific Forum of the 6th Ryskulov's Readings - Socio-Economic Modernization of Kazakhstan Under Conditions of Global Financial Instability
Author Keywords: Regional clusters; knowledge networks; network dynamics; wine industry; Kazakhstan
Abstract: Purpose - Clusters are spatial agglomerations of firms operating in the same or connected industries, which enable innovation and economic performance for firms. A wealth of empirical literature shows that one of key elements of the success of regional clusters is that they facilitate the formation of local inter-organizational networks, which act as conduits of knowledge and innovation. Methodology - While most studies analyze the benefits and characteristics of regional cluster networks and focus on advanced economies and high tech 'hot spots', this paper advances with the existing literature by analyzing network dynamics and taking an emerging economy's perspective. Originality/value - Using longitudinal data of a wine cluster in Kazakhstan and stochastic actor-oriented models for network dynamics, this paper examines what micro-level effects influence the formation of new knowledge ties among wineries. Findings - It finds that the coexistence of cohesion effects (reciprocity and transitivity) and the presence of inter-firm knowledge base heterogeneity contribute to the stability of an informal hierarchical network structure over time. Empirical results have interesting implications for cluster competitiveness and network studies, and for the burgeoning literature on corporate behavior in emerging economies.

Article Title: Study on the Impact of FDI on Industrial Structure Upgrading of Henan
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6

Abstract: This thesis analyzes the effects of foreign direct investment to the impact of industrial structure from the perspective of the upgrading of industrial structure in Henan Province, through the correlation analysis and Granger causality test between foreign direct investment and the three industries, The result shows: this is a significant effect of the upgrading of industrial structure because of the inflow of FDI, but for different industries, the upgrading effect is not the same. Article Title: Current Western Studies on Labor Relations and their Enlightenment
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF CHINA PRIVATE ECONOMY INNOVATION INTERNATIONAL FORUM 2012

Abstract: The paper, having summarized modern western academia's new focuses, perspectives and conclusions on its studies of labor relations, points out that western scholars of economics have moved their focus from class confrontations between the Employer and the Employee and the violent way of settling strikes in early times to institutional governances such as the trade union in modern times. Their attention has also been attracted to Labor Acts. The scope of their research has changed from macroscopic issues such as early class opposition to the labor disputes of some specific enterprises and industries today. How also to incentivize the Employee has become a new perspective for research.

Article Title: Analysis on the Execution of Protective Institutions of the Administrative Prosecution Right in China
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: administrative prosecution; protection of the prosecution right; judicial environment
Abstract: The imperfect protections of administrative execution right lie at the heart of the difficulty for the masses to prosecute governments. Protections are imperfect not due to institutions themselves, but because these institutions are not executed properly. That power restrains the administrative execution right may render profound consequences. To clear the channel, it is urgent to clean and improve the judicial environment for administrative prosecutions. At the meantime, the relevant problems in the administrative prosecution law itself and in its execution must be resolved.

Authors: Natarajan, K; Li, JY; Liu, JX; Koronios, A
Author Full Names: Natarajan, Kalaivany; Li, Jiuyong; Liu, Jixue; Koronios, Andy
Article Title: Rule Storage for an Efficient Rule Based Inconsistency Check
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: Data mining; Data cleaning; Association rules; Prefix tree; FP-tree
Abstract: Data inconsistency is a key source of data quality problems. Rule based methods are a major means for inconsistency checking. Association rules have been used for this purpose. Time efficiency is very important for online checking. In this paper we utilize a tree structure for efficient storage and retrieval of rules; to reduce complexity and improve efficiency. In the present work we use a storage method called prefix tree (Trie) to store and retrieve rules for making predictions on a dirty dataset. Inconsistent values are identified from large, high dimensional data sets using a large ruleset with reduced complexity in comparison to the existing methods. The number of experiments is conducted using various real world data sets to show the efficiency of our model.

Article Title: SOME APPROACHES TO THE MANAGEMENT OF HUMAN CAPITAL IN THE BUSINESS OF INNOVATION
Source Title: VITH RYSKULOV READINGS: SOCIO-ECONOMIC MODERNIZATION OF KAZAKHSTAN UNDER CONDITIONS OF GLOBAL FINANCIAL INSTABILITY
Conference Title: International Scientific Forum of the 6th Ryskulov's Readings - Socio-Economic Modernization of Kazakhstan Under Conditions of Global Financial Instability
Author Keywords: human capital; innovation; intellectual resources; human resource management; innovative development
Abstract: Purpose - is the development of theory and practical advice on managing human capital in the process of innovation development of enterprises. Methodology - the development of an innovative economy as highlighted the issues related to the description of the innovation and its results, the classification of its types and the factors driving and inhibiting innovation. These issues are reflected in the writings of scholars such as L. Vassiliev, V. A. Goremkin, V. Dorofeev, Peter F. Drucker, V. A. Dresvyannikov, P. N. Zavlin, V. Zines, and V. I. Kushlin, E. Muravyev, V. I. Podlesnykh, T. Shemyakin, Y. Yakovets. Many studies are devoted to methodological provision of innovative development. The urgency of development tools and the theoretical foundations of innovative development, the formation and use of its building at different levels of economic management are disclosed in a number of foreign and domestic scholars and practitioners. Among the domestic and foreign researchers of this issue should be made such as I. Ansoff, M. Bakanov, I. Balabanov, S. Gysina, A. Kazantsev, R. Kaplan, T. Kolosov, M. Meldahanova, P. Niven, A. Nurpeisova, O. Sabden, K. Ward, and others. The research methodology is based on the works of local and foreign scientists in the field of innovation and financial management, materials science journals, proceedings of scientists, as well as materials science and scientific conferences. The basis of the basic methods and lay the conceptual model: analysis and synthesis, comparative, study of documents, analysis of public sources. Originality/value - based on the study of theory and practice framework developed in the process of human capital management company in the process of innovation development and formulated the scientific results. In particular: - refined the concept of human capital, innovation, intellectual resources, which reflect the production and technological and managerial aspects of the enterprise int heprocessof innovation development; Identified problems of innovative positioning the company at the present stage of development of Kazakhstan's economy, based on systematic approaches for dealing with internal and external conditions of its activity. Scientific research in this article greatly complement and develop the theoretical and methodological foundations of human capital management to create an innovative environment of enterprises. Findings. 1. Refinedthe concept of innovation, intellectual resources, human capital, which reflect the production and technological and managerial aspects of the enterprise in the process of innovation development. 2. The problems of innovative development of the company at the present stage of the positioning of Kazakhstan's economy, based on systematic approaches for dealing with external and internal conditions of its activity.

Article Title: Principles of Stable Cooperation in Stochastic Games
Source Title: CONTRIBUTIONS TO GAME THEORY AND MANAGEMENT, VOL V
Book Series Title: Contributions to Game Theory and Management
Conference Title: 5th International Conference Game Theory and Management
Author Keywords: cooperative stochastic game; stationary strategies; time consistency; subgame consistency; payoff distribution procedure; strategic stability; irrational behavior proof condition
Abstract: The paper considers stochastic games in the class of stationary strategies. The cooperative form of this class of stochastic games is constructed. The cooperative solution is found. Conditions of dynamic stability for stochastic games are obtained. Principles of dynamic stability include three conditions: subgame consistency, strategic stability and irrational behavior proof condition of the cooperative agreement. Also the paper considers the example for which the cooperative agreement is found and the conditions of dynamic stability are checked.

Article Title: CHARAKTERISTICS OF SELECTED TYPES OF COMPOSTS AND THEIR IMPACT ON SOIL
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: compost; soil; microbial communities; soil organic matter
Abstract: With the advent of excessive amounts of mineral fertilizers in conventional agriculture, soil degradation in Europe has been occurring. Excessive use of mineral fertilizers also carries risks for surface water and groundwater. Therefore it is necessary to increase the use of organic fertilizers, such as compost. Correct application of compost into soil can improve physicochemical properties of the soil, it improves the activity of soil microorganisms and it also affects soil fertility. The assessment of the impact of composts must be based on appropriate criteria. In this work composts and control soil are assessed on the basis of microbial composition, amount of soil organic matter and phytotoxicity test.

Article Title: Political Connections and Soft Budget Constraints of Private Enterprises
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: political connections; private enterprises; soft budget constraints; debt leverage governance
Abstract: As the independent market entities, private enterprises enjoy distinct property rights, the budget constraints are generally considered hard. In recent years, with the vigorous development of private economy, it's getting much more popular that private companies are developing their political connections. Political connections as an alternative market mechanism can bring the enterprise financing facilities, tax incentives, market forces, and many other advantages. To some extents, political connections relax budget constraints of private enterprises. This article studied budget constraints issues of private enterprises using observations of non-financial private enterprises listed in Shanghai and Shenzhen Stock Exchanges. The results show that: Soft budget constraints do exist in Chinese private enterprises; Political connections will strengthen the soft budget constraints of private enterprises, and as the level of political connections increases, the degree of soft budget constraint gets higher.

Article Title: EFFECT OF PALM OIL AND SALMON OIL ON FATTY ACIDS COMPOSITION IN THE TISSUES OF RATS
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: palm oil; salmon oil; fatly acids; gas chromatography
Abstract: The aim of our study was to compare the effect of intake fatty acids on animal organism. Higher content of polyunsaturated fatty acids leads to decrease cholesterol and HDL cholesterol. It should prove to increase of LDL cholesterol level. 30 rats were used inour experiment. They were divided in 3 groups: control group, group with 3% addition of salmon oil a group with 3% addition of palm oil. Palm oil mainly contents saturated fatty acids (palmitic acid, 39.8%). Salmon oil contains physiologically important compounds (linolenic acid, EPA and DHA). The samples were taken after 48 days. Lliver, fat and muscle tissues were analyzed by gas chromatogramy. Determination of cholesterol was performed in animal blood. The results confirmed our mentioned prediction. The highest content of polyunsaturated acids was in the group with addition of salmon oil. This group was achieved significantly reduction in total cholesterol and HDL cholesterol. Significant increase in LDL cholesterol fraction was not proved.

Article Title: Impact of EU ascension on banks efficiency: the case of Romania and Bulgaria
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: Romania; Bulgaria; Data Envelopment Analysis; banks efficiency; European financial integration
Abstract: The European integration process is believed to provide advantages for the development of the economic environment of the candidate countries. The backbone of any modern economy is represented by the financial system, in the case of the new EU member states the banking sector being the main channel through which the economy is financed. In this context, the aim of our paper is to investigate if the ascension process to full EU membership of the countries from the 2007 extension wave, namely Bulgaria and Romania, and the preparations for the adoption of the European single currency have determined an increase of the overall efficiency of the banking sector. In order to achieve our aim, we have used a non-parametric approach based on the Data Envelopment Analysis, employing one of the most comprehensive samples of banks. The results underline an improvement of the overall efficiency of the banks operating in these countries during the analysed period of 2003-2010.

Authors: Shaikh, NK; Alhashmi, SM; Daniel, TO
Author Full Names: Shaikh, Nadia Khalique; Alhashmi, Saadat M.; Daniel, Thomas O'
Article Title: Reflection of Personalization Dissemination in Social Web
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: personalization; social networking; ubiquitous user modeling; cross system personalization
Abstract: Personalization refers to the phenomenon where users are facilitated with what they want without asking for that explicitly. Personalization is not a fully automated process; instead it refers to the circumstances where users are unable to completely communicate their desires and utilization of personalized methods can assist users towards items of interest. The personalization techniques consider various levels that include generation of useful and actionable knowledge, the inferences made using this knowledge and available domain knowledge at the time of generating the personalized experience for the user. Since there is a rapid growth in personalization of information especially web applications such as search engines, online shopping and social networks. Thus, personalized information is now omnipresent in terms of its collection and implementation. Recently most of the research streams have started asserting that the future of Social Networking is Personalization. Personalization services can take the advantage and make use of publically available data set published by social networks and enhance a user model by embedding this user information. From ubiquitous computing point of view it is significant to take account of this kind of user information. The aim of this paper is to describe personalization process and its penetration in social web by giving an overview of current research streams in academia and IT industry and highlighting the current issues.

Authors: Sobrová, P; Zítka, O; Ryvolová, M; Janu, L; Adam, V; Kizek, R
Book Editors: Skarpa, P; Ryant, P; Cerkal, R; Polak, O; Kovarnik, J; Vyskocil, I
Author Full Names: Sobrova, P.; Zitka, O.; Ryvolova, M.; Janu, L.; Adam, V; Kizek, R.
Article Title: FEMTOGRAM ELECTROCHEMICAL SENSING OF PRION PROTEINS USING QUANTUM DOTS
Conference Title: MendelNet International Ph.D. Students Conference
Author Keywords: Quantum Dot; Prion; Electrochemistry; Differential Pulse Voltammetry
Abstract: The prion protein (PrP) is involved in neurodegeneration via its conversion from the normal cellular form, PrPC, to the infectious form, PrPSc, which is the causative agent of the transmissible spongiform encephalopathies (TSEs) including Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD). In spite of great effort in this field, diagnostics of prion protein caused diseases represents a sort of challenge. In this study, we aimed our attention on studying of prion protein interaction with CdTe quantum dots (QDs) by voltammetry as a new and extremely sensitive tool for sensing of these proteins. Primarily, we characterized fluorescent and electrochemical properties of QDs. Further, electrochemical study of their interactions was carried out to find the most suitable conditions for sensitive detection of prion proteins. Detection limit (3 S/N) was estimated as 1 fg in 5 mu l. This makes labelling of proteins with QDs of great importance due to easy applicability and possibility to use in miniaturized devices, which can be used in situ. In addition, we also tested stability of the dots in vitro and in vivo using our ultrasensitive and optimized electrochemical method.

Article Title: Unintended consequences of price controls: An application to allowance markets
Source Title: JOURNAL OF ENVIRONMENTAL ECONOMICS AND MANAGEMENT
Author Keywords: Price controls; Carbon; Cap-and-trade; Allowance market; Manipulation; Price ceiling; Elasticity
Abstract: Price controls established in a cap-and-trade allowance market are intended to reduce cost uncertainty by constraining allowance prices between a ceiling and floor; however, they could provide opportunities for strategic actions by firms that would lower government revenue and increase emissions. In particular, when the ceiling price is supported by introducing new allowances into the market, firms could choose to buy allowances at the ceiling price, regardless of the prevailing market price, in order to lower the equilibrium price of all allowances. Those purchases could either be transacted by firms intending to manipulate the market price or be induced through the introduction of inaccurate information about the cost of emissions abatement. Theory and simulations using allowance elasticity estimates for U.S. firms suggest that the manipulation could be profitable under the stylized setting and assumptions evaluated in the paper, although in practice many other conditions will determine its use. Article Title: The Social Responsibility of Organizations in the 21st Century: the Case of a Romanian Faculty
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: social responsibility; corporate social responsibility; faculty; Romania
Abstract: Over the past decades the social responsibility concept has gradually gained unprecedented momentum in the public and business debates. As any other organizations, the 21st century higher education institutions have proved their focus on social responsibility. The present study is an attempt to explore the professors' opinions on the social responsibility of their faculty. Our research was based on a pilot study, an explanatory research method which allowed us a better understanding of the dimensions of the social responsibility of faculties, the elaboration of a set of hypotheses and the identification of new research directions. The aims of our paper are to present the theoretical approaches related to the concept of social responsibility of organizations, and to analyze the results of a pilot study regarding professors' opinions on this concept within a Romanian faculty. To such ends, a set of two hypotheses was tested during our research. The results of our study demonstrate that professors are not only acquainted themselves with the rhetoric of social responsibility, but are also involved in projects related to this domain. Through a better formulation of the problems and the generation of new ideas, the results of the study might constitute work hypotheses for researching on bigger and more diversified samples of professors from different faculties from Romania or abroad.

Article Title: The Effect of Multiple Management on Tourist Area: A Case Study of the World Heritage Site, Lushan, China
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: overlapping management; effect; tourist area; Lushan National Park
Abstract: It is common that tourist areas are under the management of overlapping departments due to division of the administrative region and setting of the government system. As a result, the development of tourist area is often affected by it. The authors selected the only World Culture Landscape Heritage Site in China, Lushan National Park, for a case study. It found out that many aspects of the Lushan National Park were impaired and mismanaged by the multiple and overlapping management systems, such as the overall management, the rational exploitation of resources, the integrity of scenic areas, the full tourist experience, and the intrinsic value of the World Heritage Site.

Article Title: Photographs as Visual Truth
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: photograph; visual truth; journalism; advertising science
Abstract: This paper examines and analyses the different extents to which journalism, advertising, and science use photographs to present the truth. It discusses both the unintentional and intentional truth manipulations in which practitioners in each of these fields engage in order achieve various objectives. Although human subjectivity has become increasingly involved in the processes of taking photographs, improving their quality, and choosing those that support their arguments, journalists have to do this in order to communicate cognitive meanings with the images so they can help viewers to see deeper truths beneath the pictures' superficial details. Advertising usually manipulates and distorts photographs to create dramatic effects that attract consumers. Even the most realistic advertising images do not portray the truth, but instead depict intentionally arranged objects and scenes rather than objective ones. In science, although journalists and photographs serve as a bridge between scientists and the public, photographs can portray but limited scientific truth due to the fundamental difference between scientists' and journalists' concepts of truth.

Article Title: On the Populist of the Network Expression
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: network expression; populism; group; antagonism; rational
Abstract: In the information time, cyberspace has become an important part of our daily life space and the network has become a vital channel for people to express interest demand and to participate in the country and social political life. To some extent, the inherent characteristics of network expression and core concept and basic position of populism are correlated. Currently with citizens' awareness increasing continuously and social contradictions becoming diverse, people show their opinions in an obvious populist trend which can be shown as: the existence of antagonism between official and the common people, criticism of the existing system and sentimental psychology. This populist trend can easily lead to a terrible collective irrationality and serious opposition among groups. As a result, serious division and malignant heterogeneity are formed into destructive social power. So we should take effective measures to guard against populist trend of the network expression. Firstly, the social problems should be solved and psychological mood be calmed to eliminate realistic origin of the populism of network expression. Secondly, the virtual cyberspace should be visualized and rational network expression be guided to eliminate psychological basis. Thirdly, the related laws and regulations should be perfected and behaviors of related subjects be standardized to set up the prevention and control system.

Article Title: Economic Growth and China's Carbon Dioxide Emissions: Analysis Based on Environmental Kuznets Curve
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: CO2 emissions; Economic growth; Environmental Kuznets Curve; Stationarity; Cointegration
Abstract: The aim of the paper is to explore the relationship between economic development and carbon dioxide emissions for a big developing county, China. We test whether an Environmental Kuznets Curve relationship holds for China. A cubic (N-shaped) relationship between GDP and CO2 emissions is found to fit the data most appropriately for the period 1978-2008. Furthermore, two variables are additionally significant: export reflecting the well-known pollution haven hypothesis, and agriculture value accounting for structural changes in the economy. Significant policy changes are asked for when delivering China's goods at Copenhagen Conference to cut down the CO2 emissions in the future.

Article Title: The Impact of Industrial Restructuring on GDP Growth: An Empirical Analysis for Zhejiang Province
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF CHINA PRIVATE ECONOMY INNOVATION INTERNATIONAL FORUM 2012
Conference Title: China Private Economy Innovation International Forum
Conference Sponsor: Yangtze River Delta Private Econ Res Assoc, Taizhou Branch,Journal Econ & Social Syst Comparison,Taizhou Merchant Assoc,Taizhou Univ,Ningbo Univ, Sch Business
Author Keywords: industrial structure change; GDP growth; empirical research
Abstract: This article uses the proportion of tertiary industry in GDP and the proportion of heavy industry, high-tech industries in the industrial output of Zhejiang as variables, and quantitatively analyzes the impact of changes of industrial structure on economic growth. The result shows that the industrial structure of Zhejiang Province has transited to secondary-tertiary-primary from primary-secondary-tertiary, and may further evolve into the structure of tertiary-secondary-primary in the future. The Granger causality analysis and cointegration analysis demonstrate the development of heavy industry is the leading effect on the GDP growth; they interact and reinforce each other. The development of tertiary industry and high-tech industries is an important driving force to promote economic. growth, but economic growth is not a significant cause of the former.

Article Title: Tell Me Something? Exploring the Impact of Information Privacy on User Behaviors in Social Networking Sites
Source Title: INNOVATION AND SUSTAINABLE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE: FROM REGIONAL DEVELOPMENT TO WORLD ECONOMIES, VOLS 1-5
Conference Title: 18th International-Business-Information-Management-Association Conference
Author Keywords: information privacy; user behavior; social networking sites
Abstract: The rapid growth of the Internet has multiplied the number of users from all parts of the world as well as intensified the issue of privacy. Yet the ways in which information privacy affect user behaviors others remain unclear. Furthermore, very limited number of studies has addressed the privacy concerns surrounding user behavior. Inherently, users may face a conflicting aspect of the situation-such as intense concerns for privacy competing with convenient ways of sharing knowledge over social networking sites (SNSs). With such gaps in the literature, we will explore the effect of information privacy on user behavior specifically among Middle East and North Africa (MENA) users in social networking site (SNS) activities. The overarching research question is, In what ways do information privacy induce or deter user behaviors in SNS?

Article Title: Analyses of the Double-Track Model of Pension Insurance
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6
Conference Title: International Conference on Management Innovation and Public Policy (ICMIPP)
Author Keywords: pension insurance; the double-track model; government organizations and institutions; system reform
Abstract: After decades of exploration and practice, China's Pension insurance system reform has made remarkable achievements. But because of the overall arrangement of the system, the consistency of the reform measures and other reasons, make the Pension insurance system show some problems during the development. Among them, the double-track model of pension insurance which leads to the large treatment gap between enterprises retiree and organizations and institutions retiree has become a more and more prominent, and causing widespread social concern problems in recent years, it also become one of the issues affecting social harmony. This article through the introduction of the present situation of China's double-track model of pension insurance as well as the data comparison and analysis in the specific case, discusses the problems of the double-track model of pension insurance and the reform direction of it in the future, summarized the related discussion of the double-track model of pension insurance in recent years.

Article Title: Knowledge-Based Employee Performance Evaluation System of the Generation after 1980's-Based on Analytic Hierarchy Process (AHP)
Source Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 2012 INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE ON MANAGEMENT INNOVATION AND PUBLIC POLICY (ICMIPP 2012), VOLS 1-6

Abstract: As nuclear employees of a company, the knowledge-based employees' performance will directly impact the overall preformance of the company. The knowledged workers, to support the development of enterprises as the backbone of the enterprise, are playing an increasingly important role, meanwhile, they are the key of innovation and development while they are being treating as a special group among all the stuffs. In the knowledge economy, how to play the 80s knowledge workers' enthusiasm and creativity to enhance the core competitiveness of enterprises is the key point. Article Title: Climate change and the premises for a New Society
Author Keywords: Climate change; community; eco-systems; neoclassical economics; spiritual thinking
Abstract: The starting point for this article is the excellent article by Professor Marglin on the dangers of climate change. He outlines a broad remedial prescription, a new economics based on ecological concerns and a broadly based cultural revolution to change people's thinking. We agree with Marglin that the prevailing neoclassical analysis is fundamentally flawed because inter alia it adheres to individuals' independent (rather than inter-dependent) utility functions. It is argued that ultimately the problem of the ecosystem, and indeed violent threats of mass destruction that we constantly face cannot be solved without the insights that community and spiritual thinking bring us.

Authors: Arts, B; Behagel, J; Turnhout, E; de Koning, J; van Bommel, S
Author Full Names: Arts, Bas; Behagel, Jelle; Turnhout, Esther; de Koning, Jessica; van Bommel, Severine
Article Title: A practice based approach to forest governance
Author Keywords: Forest governance; Practice based approach; Situated agency; Logic of practice; Performativity
Abstract: 'Forest governance' refers to new modes of regulation in the forest sector, such as decentralized, community-based and market-oriented policy instruments and management approaches. Its main theoretical basis consists of two mainstream models: rational choice and neo-institutionalism. Since these models rest upon problematic conceptualisations of 'the social', this paper proposes a so-called 'practice based approach', which offers a comprehensive understanding of social dynamics related to trees, forests and biodiversity. It tries to go beyond some of the old dualisms in social theory, such as subject and object, human and nature and agency and structure. Three sensitising concepts - situated agency, logic of practice and performativity - are introduced and their application is illustrated by a number of examples from forest governance practices: joint forest management in India, decentralized forest management in Bolivia and the construction of biodiversity datasets in Europe. The paper also addresses some of the criticisms the approach has received. (C) 2014 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

Authors: Chen, CM; Chang, KL; Lin, L; Lee, JL
Author Full Names: Chen, Chiang-Ming; Chang, Kuo-Liang; Lin, Lin; Lee, Jwo-Leun
Article Title: Brand switching or reduced consumption? A study of how cigarette taxes affect tobacco consumption
Author Keywords: Cigarette smoking; Brand switching; Cigarette tax
Keywords Plus: LOW-TAR; CARDIOVASCULAR-DISEASE; NICOTINE CONTENT; SMOKING; SMOKERS; RISK; TAXATION; COMPENSATION; TITRATION; BEHAVIOR
Abstract: We examined the influence of cigarette taxes on tobacco consumption, with an emphasis on smokers' choice between reducing cigarette consumption and switching brands. We constructed three scenario-based models to study the following two subjects: (1) the relationship between deciding whether to reduce one's cigarette consumption and to practice brand switching (simultaneous or sequential); (2) the key determinants that affect smokers' decisions in terms of their consumption and brand switching when facing higher taxes. We applied data collected from a survey in Taiwan, and the results indicated that both independent and two-stage decision-making models generated very similar conclusions. We also found that gender difference contributed to reduce cigarette consumption. In addition, this study indicated that high-income smokers were less likely to switch brands, whereas well-educated smokers were more likely to switch brands. Most importantly, we questioned the effectiveness of cigarette tax policy, as our results suggested that higher price did not necessarily reduce consumption. Indeed, data indicated that < 24 % of smokers actually reduced their cigarette consumption after the tax on cigarettes increased.

Authors: Dearden, L; Fitzsimons, E; Wyness, G
Author Full Names: Dearden, Lorraine; Fitzsimons, Emla; Wyness, Gill
Article Title: Money for nothing: Estimating the impact of student aid on participation in higher education
Author Keywords: Higher education participation; Higher education funding policies; Maintenance grants; Difference in differences
Abstract: Understanding how higher education (HE) finance policy can affect HE decisions is important for understanding how governments can promote human capital accumulation. Yet there is a severe lack of evidence on the effectiveness of student aid in encouraging HE participation outside of the US, and none at all for the UK. This paper exploits a reform that took place in the UK in 2004, when maintenance grants were introduced for students from low income families, having been abolished since 1999. This reform occurred in isolation of any other policy changes, and did not affect students from relatively better off families, making them a potential control group. We use a difference-in-difference framework to estimate the effect of the reform on HE undergraduate participation. We find a positive impact of maintenance grants, with a 1000 increase in grants leading to a 3.95 percentage point increase in participation. (C) 2014 The Authors. Published by Elsevier Ltd.

Article Title: A feminist response to Stephen Marglin's Premises for a New Economy
Author Keywords: Alternatives; decoloniality; ecology; gender; local economies
Abstract: In response to Stephen Marglin's call for new economies, the article points to the strong and vibrant tradition of feminist scholarship inside and outside academe, which is exploring alternatives to capitalism. The article takes up the concepts of meshworks, politics of place, feminist political ecology and community economies. It argues that feminist approaches are contributing to a new analytic that goes beyond developmentalism and recognises the importance of building a new economics based on the many progressive alternatives that are being imagined and articulated in local economic practices.

Article Title: The Health Consequences of Retirement
Abstract: This paper examines the impact of retirement on individuals' health. Declines in health commonly compel workers to retire, so the challenge is to disentangle the simultaneous causal effects. The estimation strategy employs an instrumental variables specification. The instrument is based on workers' self-reported probabilities of working past ages 62 and 65, taken from the first period in which they are observed. Results indicate that the retirement effect on health is beneficial and significant. Investigation into behavioral data, such as smoking and exercise, suggests that retirement may affect health through such channels. With additional leisure time, many retirees practice healthier habits.

Article Title: Collective consultation under quota management: China's government-led model of labour relations regulation
Author Keywords: collective bargaining; labour relations; consultation; state intervention; China
Abstract: China's system of labour relations regulation is based on a government-led model of collective consultation and contracts, driven by the central planning tradition of quota management. Government and trade unions thus cooperate to fulfil coverage quotas, especially at the local/enterprise level. Though their methods are highly successful at overcoming employers' reluctance, the absence of genuine collective bargaining leaves collective contracts largely devoid of substance. Under this system, the authors argue, the Government is institutionalizing a labour regulation framework aimed at containing the recent rise in labour unrest, while pragmatically postponing collective bargaining for the sake of stability and growth.

Article Title: Vertical Relations and Procompetitive Policy Effects in the Fund Industry: Evidence from Korea
Author Keywords: fund distributor; investor protection; market competition; policy effect; vertical relation
Abstract: This study indicates, through the first two moments (mean and variance) of distribution fees and market shares, that competition in Korea's equity fund industry has intensified since the enforcement of procompetitive policies. However, the results demonstrate that the policy effects are impeded by vertical relations among financial companies. Therefore, along with horizontal anticompetitive behaviors, fund distributors' excessive sales concentration in the affiliated funds needs to be controlled to heighten the policy effects under oligopolistic market structures. This regulation can strengthen investor protection and promote the growth of the fund industry in an emerging financial market.

Authors: Beynaghi, A; Moztarzadeh, F; Maknoon, R; Waas, T; Mozafari, M; Hugé, J; Leal, W
Author Full Names: Beynaghi, A.; Moztarzadeh, F.; Maknoon, R.; Waas, T.; Mozafari, M.; Huge, J.; Leal Filho, W.
Article Title: Towards an orientation of higher education in the post Rio+20 process: How is the game changing?
Author Keywords: Higher education; Sustainable development; Rio+20; Future; Sustainable university
Abstract: The purpose of this paper is to identify and assess the implications of sustainable development for the future orientation of higher education, especially after the 2012 United Nations Conference on Sustainable Development (Rio + 20). A qualitative trend analysis is being used for this purpose, in the context of which three macro trends are combined: (1) higher education that has been developed via five periods; (2) sustainable development that has evolved through three stages; and (3) the nexus between sustainable development and higher education which has strengthened through three phases. The simultaneous analysis of the macro trends regarding their possible interactive effects (through an expert panel discussion) demonstrates that higher education and universities under the influence of sustainable development elements are entering into a new era in which the function of higher education for sustainable development could be interpreted as the seeds of a newly emerging mission for universities. In this regard, it is expected that the concept of sustainable university is likely to become more common to meet the emerging mission. Consistent with the Rio + 20 outcomes, the authors analyzed the concept of sustainable university and identified the fact that it is practically divided into three interrelated and complementary categories, namely social-, environmental-, and economic-oriented university in pursuit of actualizing sustainable development. Authors: Julien, LA; Musy, O; Saïdi, AW
Author Full Names: Julien, Ludovic A.; Musy, Olivier; Saidi, Aurelien W.
Article Title: Exploring Duopoly Markets with Conjectural Variations
Author Keywords: strategic interactions; Lerner Index; general teaching; conjectural variations; Herfindahl Index
Abstract: In this article, the authors investigate competitive firm behaviors in a two-firm environment assuming linear cost and demand functions. By introducing conjectural variations, they capture the different market structures as specific configurations of a more general model. Conjectural variations are based on the assumption that each firm believes its own strategy influences its rival's strategy. Firms derive their optimal choice from these exogenous conjectures, under the form of a conjectural best-response function. The authors' approach fully encompasses the standard measures of market power (the Lerner Index) and concentration (the Herfindahl Index), both depending on the conjectural variations. They finally represent, analytically and graphically, the equilibrium strategies and the associated indexes in a unified framework for any level of competition, ranging from perfect competition to collusion.

Article Title: CHANGING SUPPLY AND DEMAND FOR FISH OIL
Author Keywords: salmon farming; nutraceuticals; aquaculture; omega-3; fish oil; rapeseed oil
Abstract: Competition for fish oil from human nutritional supplements (nutraceuticals) is starting to threaten its supply for aquaculture feeds. World supply of fish oil is not increasing but is the main source of healthy omega-3 fats (n-3 LC-PUFA). Fish oil demand by nutraceuticals is a derived demand for such fats. Demand growth and insecure supply are causing price inflation of fish oil, helping to drive its substitution in aquaculture feeds by vegetable oils. This is reducing the content of n-3 LC-PUFA in aquaculture products, especially salmon, with potentially negative health implications. Given the scope for further substitution of fish oil, it is unlikely that future growth of global aquaculture will be constrained by reducing omega-3 content, although it will complicate consumer marketing of salmon. Nutraceuticals is paying more than aquaculture for fish oil based on omega-3 content, but novel sources of n-3 LC-PUFA will become available in the medium term.

Authors: Andersen, PD; Andersen, AD; Jensen, PA; Rasmussen, B
Author Full Names: Andersen, Per Dannemand; Andersen, Allan Dahl; Jensen, Per Anker; Rasmussen, Birgitte
Article Title: Sectoral innovation system foresight in practice: Nordic facilities management foresight
Author Keywords: Foresight; Sectoral innovation system; Facilities management; Priority setting of research; Nordic
Keywords Plus: TECHNOLOGY FORESIGHT; CORPORATE FORESIGHT; FUTURES; EXPERIENCES; MEGATRENDS; IMPACT; ROLES
Abstract: A number of studies have explored the interconnection between the foresight literature and the innovation system literature. This paper adds to these studies by investigating how theoretical elements of the innovation system approach can contribute to the design and practice of foresight processes. The paper originates in a foresight project in the Nordic facilities management sector. The goal of the foresight project was to identify the possible futures of the facilities management sector in the Nordic countries (Denmark, Finland, Norway, and Sweden) and, based on the findings, to establish a proposal for a common Nordic facilities management research agenda. The paper finds that three elements of the innovation system literature are of particular interest for the practice of foresight: innovation systems and context dependency, learning and user-producer interactions, and the role of knowledge and knowledge production. These elements are embedded into a simple sectoral innovation system model (including actors, knowledge flows, and the strategic environment). (C) 2014 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

Authors: Cerri, KH; Knapp, M; Fernandez, JL
Author Full Names: Cerri, Karin H.; Knapp, Martin; Fernandez, Jose-Luis
Article Title: Public funding of pharmaceuticals in the Netherlands: investigating the effect of evidence, process and context on CVZ decision-making
Author Keywords: Health technology assessment; HTA; CVZ; Payer decision-making; Reimbursement; Coverage; Pharmaceuticals; Appraisal; Dutch reimbursement
Abstract: The College Voor Zorgverzekeringen (CVZ) provides guidance to the Dutch healthcare system on funding and use of new pharmaceutical technologies. This study examined the impact of evidence, process and context factors on CVZ decisions in 2004-2009. A data set of CVZ decisions pertaining to pharmaceutical technologies was created, including 29 variables extracted from published information. A three-category outcome variable was used, defined as the decision to 'recommend', 'restrict' or 'not recommend' a technology. Technologies included in list 1A/1B or on the expensive drug list were considered recommended; those included in list 2 or for which patient co-payment is required were considered restricted; technologies not included on any reimbursement list were classified as 'not recommended'. Using multinomial logistic regression, the relative contribution of explanatory variables on CVZ decisions was assessed. In all, 244 technology appraisals (256 technologies) were analysed, with 51 %, of technologies recommended, 33 % restricted and 16 % not recommended by CVZ for funding. The multinomial model showed significant associations (p a parts per thousand currency sign 0.10) between CVZ outcome and several variables, including: (1) use of an active comparator and demonstration of statistical superiority of the primary endpoint in clinical trials, (2) pharmaceutical budget impact associated with introduction of the technology, (3) therapeutic indication and (4) prevalence of the target population. Results confirm the value of a comprehensive and multivariate approach to understanding CVZ decision-making.

Article Title: MICHIGAN AND OHIO K-12 EDUCATIONAL FINANCING SYSTEMS: EQUALITY AND EFFICIENCY
Abstract: We consider issues of equality and efficiency in two different school funding systems-a state-level system in Michigan and a foundation system in Ohio. Unlike Ohio, the Michigan system restricts districts from generating property or income tax revenue to fund operating expenditures. In both states, districts fund capital expenditures with local tax revenue. Our results indicate that although average revenue and expenditures per pupil in Michigan and Ohio are almost identical, the distributions of the various revenue sources are quite different. Ohio's funding system has greater equality in terms of total revenue, largely due to Ohio redistributing state funds to the least wealthy districts while Michigan does not. We find relatively wealthy Michigan districts spend more on capital expenditures, whereas relatively wealthy Ohio districts spend more on labor and materials. This suggests that constraints on raising local revenue to fund operating expenditures in Michigan could create efficiency issues.

Article Title: Commodities and Macroeconomic Factors: Unconditional Volatility Measures
Author Keywords: information criteria; robust Granger causality testing; unconditional and conditional volatility
Abstract: This study focuses on the measurement of spillover effects from macroeconomic factors to commodity volatility. It argues that such measurement is sensitive to volatility computation and to causality testing. To this end, I analyze two commodity data sets-gold and the Continuous Commodity Index (1969-2011), and twenty-four Dow Jones futures indexes (1991-2011)-and various macroeconomic indicators. I conclude that the macroeconomic factors that influence volatility generally depend on the commodity under consideration. I also explore whether commodities of the same class experience volatility shifts around the same dates, and find that this is not the case except for energy commodities.

Article Title: Estimating Heterogeneous Takeup and Crowd-Out Responses to Existing Medicaid Income Limits and their Nonmarginal Expansions
Keywords Plus: HEALTH-INSURANCE COVERAGE; PRIVATE INSURANCE; INSTRUMENTAL VARIABLES; CHILDREN; ELIGIBILITY; MODELS; PARTICIPATION; REGRESSION; PROGRAM; WOMEN
Abstract: We use a switching pro bit model and the income-limit-based structure of Medicaid eligibility for children to estimate treatment effects of nonmarginal Medicaid expansions on Medicaid takeup, private insurance coverage, and crowd-out, as well as crowd-out for those eligible for Medicaid under rules already in place. Many of these estimates are not found in existing work on public insurance and cannot be calculated with the linear probability model used by previous work in this literature. We provide an estimation approach that is straightforward to implement yet yields precise treatment effects.

Article Title: The Comovements of Capital Inflows in the Frequency Domain: Evidence from Emerging Countries
Author Keywords: cohesion; comovements of capital inflows; cross-cohesion; dynamic correlation; frequency domain analysis
Abstract: This paper analyzes the correlations between capital inflows and business cycles in emerging countries, and also investigates the comovements of capital inflows, by capital types, within and across regions (Asia, Latin America, and Europe) in the frequency domain. In general, bank loans show positive correlations with business cycles at all frequencies across emerging countries. In addition, I find that the dynamic correlations between capital types are high at low frequencies and become lower at the higher frequency domains. The cohesion (comovements within a region) and cross-cohesion (comovements across regions) differ in accordance with the capital types and frequency domains.

Article Title: Convergence of Bank Efficiency in Emerging Markets: The Experience of Central and Eastern European Countries
Author Keywords: banking; CEE countries; convergence; efficiency; frontier analysis
Keywords Plus: TRANSITION ECONOMIES; COST EFFICIENCY; PERFORMANCE; FOREIGN; PRODUCTIVITY; OWNERSHIP; PRIVATIZATION; DETERMINANTS; SUPERVISION; COMPETITION
Abstract: In this study, we investigate the effect of the European Union integration process on banks' efficiency and the convergence of cost efficiency across banking systems from Central and Eastern European countries for the period 2004-10. We observe large differences in the levels of cost efficiency among national banking systems, and we notice an increase in banking efficiency for all banking systems until 2008. However, starting with 2009, the evolution of the average scores of cost efficiency declines. The results provide evidence of beta-convergence and sigma-convergence in terms of cost efficiency among the banking systems, especially during the period 2009-10.

Article Title: Children of War The Long-Run Effects of Large-Scale Physical Destruction and Warfare on Children
Abstract: This paper provides causal evidence on the long-term consequences of large-scale physical destruction on educational attainment, health status, and labor market outcomes of children. I exploit the plausibly exogenous region-by-cohort variation in the intensity of World War Two (WWII) destruction as a unique quasi-experiment. I find that exposure to destruction had long-lasting detrimental effects on the human capital formation, health, and labor market outcomes of Germans who were at school-age during WWII. An important channel for the effect of destruction on educational attainment is the destruction of schools whereas malnutrition is partly behind the estimated impact on health.

Article Title: The Quest for Accountable Governance: Embedded NGOs and Demand Driven Advocacy in the International Trade Regime
Keywords Plus: EPISTEMIC COMMUNITIES; MULTILEVEL GOVERNANCE; WTO; ORGANIZATIONS; LIBERALISM; POWER
Abstract: The ongoing failure of the multilateral trade regime to deliver on global development priorities has produced a new brand of expert. Embedded NGOs have emerged with the expressed aim to socially embed global markets, carve out additional policy or development space for developing countries, increase their negotiating capacity, and promote the three pillars of sustainable development economic, social and environment. Eschewing conventional advocacy or protest work that challenges received wisdom, Embedded NGOs leverage their legal and technical trade-related expertise across a range of issue areas that are of primary concern to poor countries. This article develops a conceptual framework for analysing the impact of Embedded NGOs on the World Trade Organization's (WTO) accountability regime. While Embedded NGOs show good prospects for improving the inclusion and negotiating capacity of developing countries, the institutional and geographical attributes of Embedded NGOs, the uneven engagement by Embedded NGOs with developing countries, their commitment to a liberal economic order, and the internal and external accountability of Embedded NGOs themselves serve to reinforce dominant trade narratives and power asymmetries in global trade.

Article Title: Testing the red herring hypothesis on an aggregated level: ageing, time-to-death and care costs for older people in Sweden
Author Keywords: Mortality; Long-term care; Red herring
Abstract: In this paper we test the 'red herring' hypothesis for expenditures on long-term care (LTC). The main contribution of this paper is to assess the 'red herring' hypothesis by using the probability of dying as a measure for time-to-death (TTD). In addition, we implement models that allow for age-specific TTD effects on LTC utilization as well as sex-specific effects. We also focus on total, institutional and domiciliary LTC separately. For our analysis we use high quality administrative data from Sweden. Our analysis is based on fixed effects estimates. We use our findings to project future LTC expenditures and show that, although TTD is a relevant predictor, age itself remains the main driver of LTC expenditures.

Article Title: The Financial Cost of Rivalry: A Tale of Two South Asia Neighbors
Author Keywords: confidence-building measures; emerging markets; military news; political risk; spillovers; VAR-EGARCH
Keywords Plus: MACROECONOMIC CONSEQUENCES; STOCK MARKETS; VOLATILITY; RETURNS; TRANSMISSION; TERRORISM; PRICE; RISK; WAR
Abstract: We examine the effect of bilateral political and military news on the returns and volatility of the stock markets of India and Pakistan. Our results show that the volatility of both stock markets shows a significant reaction on the arrival of news related to military aggression in a reciprocal way. Moreover, while the volatility of India's stock market seems to show a subdued response to bilateral political news, Pakistan's stock market appears to be sensitive to both political and military news originating from either country. The relatively stronger effect of military events can be attributed to a higher financial cost of confrontation between the two countries.

Article Title: Orphan drugs policies: a suitable case for treatment
Author Keywords: Rare diseases; Cost-effectiveness analysis; Drug reimbursement; Health technology assessment
Abstract: Current orphan drug policies are unsatisfactory when viewed from almost all perspectives. Patients find that, although therapies are available for many rare conditions, access to care is sometimes restricted. Pharmaceutical manufacturers have responded to the incentives for research embodied in orphan drug legislation, only to find that funds are not made available to pay for therapies once developed. Those funding health care find that most orphan drugs do not justify funding based on standard value for money criteria, yet that they face political problems if they fail to provide funding for therapy. A literature review was conducted in order to determine the precise nature of the problems and to suggest potential solutions. Current orphan drug policies are not fit for the purpose and initiatives need to be taken in the areas of (1) clarifying society's views about the priority to be given to orphan drugs, (2) revising the arrangements for pricing and reimbursement of orphan drugs, (3) defining the priorities for research into rare diseases and (4) developing 'joined up' policies to deal with these issues. Without changes in the current policies, pharmaceutical companies will eventually cease responding to the incentives to develop orphan drugs, because they will increasingly be uncertain whether the drugs, if developed, will be reimbursed.

Authors: Lou, F; Wang, JW; Yuan, HQ
Author Full Names: Lou, Fang; Wang, Jiwei; Yuan, Hongqi
Article Title: Stock Liquidity and the Pricing of Earnings: A Comparison of China's Floating and Nonfloating Shares
Author Keywords: China; earnings; pricing; stock liquidity
Abstract: The reform aimed at converting nonfloating shares to floating shares in China provides a setting in which shares are subject to different levels of liquidity constraints. We show that the severity of these constraints is inversely related to the extent to which earnings information is reflected in share prices. Specifically, before the reform, transfer prices of nonfloating shares reflect much less earnings information than the market prices of floating shares. After the reform, however, transfer prices of nonfloating shares reflect more earnings information, although the weights are still less than those found in market prices. Thus, China's unique setting shows that share liquidity affects the way earnings are priced in stock.

Authors: Michael, MD; Bálint, A; Lovász, BD; Gulácsi, L; Strbák, B; Golovics, PA; Farkas, K; Kürti, Z; Szilágyi, BK; Mohás, A; Molnár, T; Lakatos, PL
Author Full Names: Michael, Mandel D.; Balint, Anita; Lovasz, Barbara D.; Gulacsi, Laszlo; Strbak, Balint; Golovics, Petra A.; Farkas, Klaudia; Kuerti, Zsuzsanna; Szilagyi, Blanka K.; Mohas, Anna; Molnar, Tamas; Lakatos, Peter L.
Article Title: Work disability and productivity loss in patients with inflammatory bowel diseases in Hungary in the era of biologics
Author Keywords: UC; CD; Work disability; Productivity loss; Anti-TNF; Hungary
Keywords Plus: QUALITY-OF-LIFE; CROHNS-DISEASE; RHEUMATOID-ARTHRITIS; ULCERATIVE-COLITIS; INDIRECT COSTS; BURDEN; EUROPE
Abstract: Background and aims To assess work disability (WD) rates in an inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) cohort involving patients with Crohn's disease (CD) or ulcerative colitis (UC) cohort and to identify possible clinical or demographic factors associated with WD. To our knowledge, this is the first study from Eastern Europe that has estimated indirect costs in IBD. Methods Data from 443 (M/F: 202/241, CD/UC: 260/183, mean age: 35.5 (CD) and 40.5 (UC) years, biological drug exposure 31.2/11.5 %) consecutive patients were included. WD data were collected by questionnaire and the work productivity and activity impairment instrument. Disability pension (DP) rates in the general population were retrieved from public databases. Results The overall DP rate in this IBD population was 32.3 %, with partial disability in 24.2 %. Of all DP events, 88.8 % were directly related to IBD. Overall, full DP was more prevalent in IBD (RR: 1.51, p < 0.001) and CD (RR: 1.74, p < 0.001) but not in UC compared to the general population and also in CD compared to UC (OR 1.57, p = 0.03). RR for full DP was increased only in young CD patients (RR<35 year olds: 9.4; RR36-40 year olds: 9.4 and 5.6, p < 0.01 for both). In CD, age group, previous surgery, disease duration, frequent relapses, and the presence of arthritis/arthralgia were associated with an increased risk for DP. Among employed patients, absenteeism and presenteeism was reported in of 25.9 and 60.3 % patients, respectively, leading to a 28 % loss of work productivity and a 32 % activity loss, and was associated with disease activity and age group. Average cost of productivity loss due to disability and sick leave with a human capital approach was 1,450 and 430 (sic)/patient/year in IBD, respectively (total productivity loss 1,880 (sic)/patient/year), the costs of presenteeism were 2,605 (SD = 2,770) and 2,410 (SD = 2,970) (sic)/patient/year in CD and UC, respectively. Conclusion Risk of DP was highly increased in young CD patients (sixfold to ninefold). Previous surgery and presence of arthritis/arthralgia was identified as risk factors for DP. Work productivity is significantly impaired in IBD and is associated with high productivity loss.

Article Title: Counting Care Work in Social Policy: Valuing Unpaid Child- and Eldercare in Korea
Author Keywords: care policies; time use; Valuing unpaid care; unpaid care
Abstract: This study demonstrates the usefulness of quantifying and valuing time spent on unpaid care work and explores the links between social policies, unpaid care work, and gender equality in the context of recent social care reforms in the Republic of Korea. Using information provided by two nationally representative surveys, this article elaborates on the gendered organization of care provision and the total costs of care services for children and the elderly, including unpaid family care, family expenditures on care services, and state support in the form of public expenditures. The study finds that omitting the role of family care services overestimates the state's role in caring for children and elderly adults. A closer look at the impact of long-term care insurance reveals the need for integrated analyses of the qualitative and quantitative aspects of the social organization of care, especially in regard to gender equality.
